item.title: Aphytis chilensis
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chilensis Howard

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: Cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An important parasitoid of the oleander scale, Aspidiotus nerii Bouche.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.5 to 1.1 mm; smaller specimens are paler, bear less setae and were even described as a separate species (Aphytis riadi).

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis chilensis is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield onto the host’s body.

(Figure 1)

Due to the fact that at molting the shields of these insects adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter (meconia). The pupa is free, and its eyes change from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although reared (in the field and in the laboratory) from several hosts, it seems to prefer the oleander scale. Aphytis chilensis is thelytokous (but males have been described), requiring ca 18 days to complete a generation at 28°C and each female produces about 25 offspring. In the field the parasitoid has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn. It attacks mainly young host females and is a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization.

Water extract of the shield of the oleander scale elicited a positive response from A. chilensis, suggesting that its host-searching is based on chemical cues.

References

Alexandrakis, V. and Neuenschwander, P. 1980. Le role d’Aphytis chilensis (Hym.: Aphelinidae), parasite d’Aspidiotus nerii (Hom.: Diaspididae) sur olivier en Crete. Entomophaga 25: 61-71.

Gerson, U. 1967. Aphytis riadi - a synonym of A. chilensis (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Annals of the Entomological Society of America 60: 1116-1118.

Lo Pinto, M., Lo Bue, P., Peri, E. Agrò, A., Liotta, G. and Colazza, S. 2002. Responses of 2003. Aphytis chilensis to the synthetic sex pheromone of the oleander scale. IOBC/WPRS Bulletin 25():

Luck, R.F. and Uygun, N. 1986. Host recognition and selection by Aphytis species: response to California red, oleander and cactus scale cover extracts. Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata 40: 129-136.

Rosen, D. and DeBach, P. 1978. Species of Aphytis of the World (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Israel Universities Press, Jerusalem.

Websites:

item.title: Aphytis chrysomphali
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis chrysomphali (Mercet)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Probably a native of the Mediterranean basin; its distribution is now almost cosmopolitan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii (Maskell).

Economic importance: A member of a guild of parasitoids that attack the California red scale. In Israel and Cyprus A. chrysomphali occurs only along the coastal plain.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size is from 0.6 to 1.0 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, A. chrysomphali is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the ectoparasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the host’s shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Although obtained from several armored scale hosts, it is best known as a parasitoid of the California red scale. Aphytis chrysomphali is a uniparental thelytokous species (with rare males) and a voracious host feeder, killing more scales by this practice than by parasitization. It completes a cycle in a fortnight at 25°C, at which temperature each female produces about 25 offspring. It appears to be tolerant to low temperatures but susceptible to heat and aridity, attributes that could explain its prevalence along the coastal plain.

References

Orphanides, G.M. 1996. Establishment of Comperiella bifasciata (Hym: Encyrtidae) on Aonidiella aurantii (Hom: Diaspididae) in Cyprus. Entomophaga 41: 53-57.

Rosen, D. and DeBach, P. 1978. Species of Aphytis of the World (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Israel Universities Press, Jerusalem.

Websites:

item.title: Aphytis coheni
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis coheni DeBach

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Probably a native of south-east Asia that had fortuitously arrived in Israel and Lebanon.

Hosts: California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii (Maskell), rarely other armored scale insects (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An important natural enemy of the California red scale, especially in the inner, warmer and drier parts of Israel.

Morphology: The female is yellow, about 0.8 to 1.1 mm in length.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis coheni is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are attacked, but the young ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (meconia). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. The California red scale is its major host, although the ectoparasitoid was also obtained from a few other armored scale hosts. Aphytis coheni is arrhenotokous, requiring 3-4 weeks at 20°C to complete a generation, 12 days at 28°C. Each female, whether mated or not, produces about 25 offspring; the parasitoid may place an average of 5 eggs in such hosts. At 24°C males live about three weeks, females slightly longer. Aphytis coheni is a voracious host feeder that kills twice as many scales by this practice than by parasitization.

In the field the populations of A. coheni have a mild spring peak. Its juveniles, which are protected during their development by the host’s shield, seem to be tolerant to high temperatures, but the adults, and especially the males, are very susceptible. The parasitoid’s presence in the inner, hotter and drier regions of Israel is probably due to lack of competition there from other parasitoids of the California red scale (which are more susceptible to arid conditions), not due to any intrinsic superior biological attributes.

Water extracts of the shield of the California red scale elicited positive responses from A. coheni, indicating that its host searching is based on chemical cues.

References

Avidov, Z., M. Balshin and U. Gerson. 1970. Studies on Aphytis coheni, a parasite of the California red scale, Aonidiella aurantii, in Israel. Entomophaga 15: 191-207.

Luck, R.F. and Uygun, N. 1986. Host recognition and selection by Aphytis species: response to California red, oleander and cactus scale cover extracts. Entomologia Experimentalis et Applicata 40 : 129-136.

Websites:

item.title: Aphytis hispanicus
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis hispanicus (Mercet)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: The Mediterranean Basin, Central America, Texas, California, Taiwan.

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandiiComstock and tropical grey chaff scale, Parlatoria cinereaHadden. In the laboratory the parasitoid can be reared on the latania scale, Hemiberlesia lataniae(Signoret).

Economic importance: A parasitoid of chaff scales.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.6 to 1.0 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis hispanicus is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The 2nd-stage nymphs, young females and scale prepupae are sometimes attacked, but the ovipositing females are the preferred stage for parasitization. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the scales and prior to pupation they excrete their fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The pupa is free, its eyes changing from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of its age. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. A. hispanicus is a uniparental thelytokous species, requiring about a fortnight to complete a generation at 28°C, each female producing about 24 offspring. In the field this solitary parasitoid has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn, being rare during summer and winter. It attacks its chaff scale hosts mostly on the leaves, less on the fruit and very seldom on the wooden parts of the trees, and does not feed on its hosts.

References

Gerson, U. 1967. The natural enemies of the chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandii Comstock, in Israel. Entomophaga 12: 97-109.

Gerson, U. 1968. The comparative biologies of two hymenopterous parasites of the chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandii. Entomophaga 13: 163-173.

Rosen, D. and DeBach, P. 1978. Species of Aphytis of the World (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Israel Universities Press, Jerusalem.

item.title: Aphytis holoxanthus
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Aphytis holoxanthus DeBach

Taxonomic placing: , Holometabola, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Geographical distribution: Of South-Eastern Asia origin, this species was successfully introduced into Israel in 1956/57 and later into Australia, Florida, South Africa and South America.

Host: The Florida red scale, Chrysomphalus aonidum (L.) (Diaspididae).

Economic importance: An efficient natural enemy of the Florida red scale.

Morphology: The female is yellow, its size being from 0.7 to 0.9 mm.

Life cycle: Like other members of its genus, Aphytis holoxanthus is an ectoparasitoid of armored scale insects. The eggs are deposited through the shield on the host’s body; due to the fact that when molting the shields of these scales adhere to their bodies, the parasitoid can deposit only between molts. Its emerging larvae feed on the host and kill it; prior to pupation the larvae excrete their meconia. The pupa is free, and its eyes change from colorless to red to green, providing an indication of age. The adult emerges through an exit hole in the shield or by crawling out from underneath. It attacks 2nd-stage female scales, male pupae but mostly adult females, on which two or three juveniles may develop. It is an arrhenotokous species, requiring a fortnight to complete a generation at 28°C, each female producing about 35 offspring.

Aphytis holoxanthus has not become established in the inner, arid valleys of Israel. When co-occurring with another natural enemy of the Florida red scale, the endoparasitoid Pteroptrix smithi (Compere), the latter appears to be dominant. This may reflect the latter’s ability to parasitize all scale stages (whereas A. holoxanthus can attack the host only between its molts), to the reduced activity of A. holoxanthus on citrus fruit, and to its greater susceptibility to organophosphate pesticides. On the other hand, the parasite has not been affected by the acaricide dicofol or by juvenile hormone analoge IGR.

References

Peleg, B.A. 1988. Effect of a new phenoxy juvenile hormone analog on California red scale (Homoptera, Diaspididae), Florida wax scale (Homoptera, Coccidae) and the ectoparasitic Aphytis holoxanthus DeBach (Hymenoptera, Aphelinidae). Journal of Economic Entomology 81: 88-92.

Rehman, S.U., Browning, H.W., Nigg, H.N. and Harrison, J.M. 1999. Residual effects of carbaryl and dicofol on Aphytis holoxanthus Debach (Hymenoptera : Aphelinidae). Biological Control 16: 252-257.

Rosen, D. and DeBach, P. 1978. Species of Aphytis of the World (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Israel Universities Press , Jerusalem.

Steinberg, S., Podoler, H. and Rosen, D. 1986. Biological control of the Florida red scale, Chrysomphalus aonidum, in Israel by two parasite species: current status in the coastal plain. Phytoparasitica 14: 199-204.

Steinberg, S., Podoler, H. and Rosen, D. 1987. Competition between two parasites of the Florida red scale in Israel. Ecological Entomology 12: 299-310.

Websites:

item.title: Encarsia inquirenda
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Encarsia inquirenda (Silvestri)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: The Mediterranean Basin

Hosts: Several armored scale insects (Diaspididae), especially chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandiiComstock and tropical grey chaff scale, Parlatoria cinereaHadden. It also attacks the olive scale, Parlatoria oleae(Colvee). In the laboratory the parasitoid can be reared on the latania scale, Hemiberlesia lataniae(Signoret).

Economic importance: A parasitoid of chaff scales.

Morphology: The female is dark yellow, its size being from 0.6 to 0.9 mm.

Life cycle: Encarsia inquirenda is a solitary endoparasitoid of chaff scales, attacking all stages, including the male prepupae and the females. The egg is inserted through the shield into the host’s body whereon the emerging larva feeds. Parasitized 2nd-stage male nymphs, whose bodies become bloated due the larva’s presence, continue to build their shields, which thus become rounded instead of elongated. Parasitized chaff scales gradually turn white, losing their purplish color, and then become mummified. Prior to pupation the larva excretes its fecal matter in the shape of black pellets (”meconia”). The development of the parasitoid is undisturbed by the host’s molts. The adult often emerges through an exit hole in the shield, or by crawling out from underneath. Encarsia inquirenda is a uniparental (thelytokous) species, requiring about four weeks to complete a generation at 28°C, each female producing about 20 offspring. In the field the parasitoid, which is relatively tolerant to low humidities, has two population peaks, in spring and in autumn, being rare during summer and winter. It attacks its chaff scale hosts mostly on the fruit and leaves, rarely on the wooden parts of the trees, and does not feed on its hosts.

References

Gerson, U. 1967. The natural enemies of the chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandii Comstock, in Israel. Entomophaga 12 97-109.

Gerson, U. 1968. The comparative biologies of two hymenopterous parasites of the chaff scale, Parlatoria pergandii. Entomophaga 13 163-173.

Websites: http://chalcidoids.tamu.edu/ENCARSIA/encarsia.htm

<

item.title: Encarsia lahorensis
item.author: Uri Gerson
item.description:
Encarsia lahorensis (Howard)

Taxonomic placing: Insecta, Hymenoptera, Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae.

Common name: None.

Geographical distribution: Encarsia lahorensis, of south Asian provenance, was initially introduced into California and has accompanied its host, the citrus whitefly, wherever it became established.

Hosts: The citrus whitefly, Dialeurodes citri (Ashmead) (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae).

Economic importance: Encarsia lahorensis is the most important and most commonly employed natural enemy of the citrus whitefly, killing the pest by parasitization as well as by host feeding. In Israel the pest was completely controlled by this natural enemy.

Morphology: The body of the female is 0.55-0.85 mm long, and lemon-yellow in color; the smaller male (0.60 mm long) has a brown abdomen.

Life cycle: Encarsia lahorensis is a solitary, primary endoparasitoid; its fertilized (diploid) eggs are deposited in the fourth instar larvae of the host. Unfertilized (haploid) eggs are inserted into the body of the whitefly host and placed on the body of its own female larva, the males thus being hyperparasites on their own (or sometimes of other endoparasitoid) females. Eggs are deposited within the first 7-10 days of the adult life (20 to 50 eggs per female), and a generation is raised in 17 to 25 days. Under laboratory condition (26°C, 70% RH) females live about 9 days and the males 11 days. Encarsia lahorensis overwinters as both larvae and pupae.

References

Argov, Y., Rossler, Y., Voet, H. and Rosen, D. 2000. Introducing Encarsia lahorensis against Dialeurodes citri in Israel: a case of successful biological control. BioControl 45: 1-10.

Argov, Y. and Rossler, Y. 1986. The introduction of Encarsia lahorensis(Howard) (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae) into Israel for the control of the citrus whitefly, Dialeurodes citri(Ashmead) (Homoptera: Aleyrodidae). Israel Journal of Entomology 20: 1-5.

Nguyen, R. 1986. Encarsia lahorensis(Howard) a parasite of Dialeurodes citri(Ashmead) (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae). Florida Department Agriculture Consumer services, Entomology Circular 290, 2 pp.

Rose, M. and DeBach P. 1981. Citrus whitefly parasites established in California. California Agriculture 35: 21-23.

Viggiani, G. and Mazzone, P. 1978. Morfologia, biologia e utilizzazione di Prospaltella lahorensis How. (Hym. Aphelinidae), parassita esotico introdotto in Italia per la lotta biologica al Dialeurodes citri (Ashm.). Bolletino di Laboratorio Entomologia Agraria “Filippo Silvestri” Portici 35: 99-161.

Contact: Yael Argov The Israel Cohen Institute for Biological Control, Citrus Marketing Board of Israel, P.O. Box 80, 50250 Bet Dagan, Israel. E-mail: yael@jaffa.co.il

Websites:

http://chalcidoids.tamu.edu/ENCARSIA/encarsia.htm
